qas.question: What were non-Muslim groups under the Umayyads called?
Along with Berbers, Zoroastrians and Christians, what notable non-Muslim group existed in the Umayyad Caliphate?
Along with Jews, what non-Muslim religion produced notable theological works under the Umayyads?
What were Muslim groups in the Umayyad Caliphate called?
Who was given a legally protected status as first class citizens?
What were Muslims banned from holding in the empire?
What led to a lack of great thinkers in Muslim communities?

plausible_answers.text: the political supremacy of the ruling Muslims

qas.question: What were non-Muslims not required to acknowledge?

context: Non-Muslim groups in the Umayyad Caliphate, which included Christians, <a1_0>Jews<a1_0/>, Zoroastrians, and pagan Berbers, were called <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>dhimmis<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/>. They were given a legally protected status as second-class citizens as long as they accepted and acknowledged <b7_0>the political supremacy of the ruling Muslims<b7_0/>. They were allowed to have their own courts, and were given freedom of their religion within the empire.[citation needed] Although they could not hold <b5_0>the highest public offices<b5_0/> in the empire, they had many bureaucratic positions within the government. <a2_0>Christians<a2_0/> and Jews still continued to produce great theological thinkers within their communities, but as time wore on, many of the <b6_0>intellectuals converted<b6_0/> to Islam, leading to a lack of great thinkers in the non-Muslim communities.
